recipes.name: Hainanese Chicken Rice
ingredients: Soy sauce and sesame oil for serving
Cucumber slices and cilantro for garnish
steps: Rinse the chicken, inside and out. Pat dry with paper towels.
In a large pot of boiling water, submerge the chicken and simmer for about 45-60 minutes, or until cooked through. Remove and let it cool.
In a large skillet, heat the vegetable oil over medium heat. Add the minced garlic and ginger, and sauté until fragrant.
Add the rice and stir to coat with the garlic and ginger mixture. Transfer the rice to a rice cooker and add the chicken stock. Cook according to the rice cooker's instructions.
Once the chicken is cool, rub it with salt and optionally, a bit of sesame oil. Slice the chicken.
Serve the chicken over the cooked rice. Garnish with cucumber slices and cilantro. Serve with soy sauce and sesame oil on the side.

recipes.name: Char Kway Teow
ingredients: Bean sprouts, chives, and lime wedges for garnish
steps: Soak the flat rice noodles in hot water for about 15 minutes until softened. Drain and set aside.
In a large wok, heat the vegetable oil over high heat. Add the minced garlic and stir-fry until fragrant.
Add the prawns and Chinese sausage, and cook until the prawns turn pink and the sausage is slightly caramelized.
Push the ingredients to one side of the wok and pour the beaten eggs into the empty side. Scramble until just set, then mix with the other ingredients.
Add the soaked noodles, dark soy sauce, light soy sauce, oyster sauce, and chili paste. Stir-fry until well combined and heated through.
Serve the Char Kway Teow with bean sprouts, chives, and lime wedges for garnish.

recipes.name: Chilli Crab
steps: Heat the vegetable oil in a large wok or skillet over medium heat. Add the minced garlic and ginger, and stir-fry until fragrant.
Add the crab halves and cook for a few minutes until they turn pink.
Pour the beaten egg over the crab and stir until the egg is cooked and coats the crab.
Stir in the sambal chili paste, ketchup, sweet chili sauce, soy sauce, oyster sauce, and sugar. Cook until well combined and heated through.
Season with salt to taste. Garnish with chopped cilantro before serving.

recipes.name: Laksa
ingredients: Bean sprouts, lime wedges, and chopped cilantro for garnish
steps: Cook the rice vermicelli according to package instructions. Drain and set aside.
In a large pot, heat the vegetable oil over medium heat. Add the minced garlic and stir-fry until fragrant.
Add the laksa paste and cook for a few minutes until fragrant.
Pour in the chicken broth and bring to a simmer. Add the prawns and tofu puffs, and cook until the prawns turn pink.
Stir in the coconut milk and cooked chicken. Simmer for a few more minutes.
Divide the cooked rice vermicelli into bowls. Ladle the laksa soup over the noodles.
Garnish with boiled eggs, bean sprouts, lime wedges, and chopped cilantro.

recipes.name: Bak Kut Teh
ingredients: 1 packet bak kut teh spice mix
10 dried shiitake mushrooms, soaked and halved
Salt and white pepper to taste
Chopped green onions and cilantro for garnish
steps: Blanch the pork ribs in boiling water for a few minutes to remove impurities. Drain and set aside.
In a large pot, heat the vegetable oil over medium heat. Add the minced garlic and sliced ginger, and sauté until fragrant.
Add the blanched pork ribs and shiitake mushrooms. Stir-fry for a few minutes.
Pour in the water and add the bak kut teh spice mix. Bring to a boil, then reduce heat and let it simmer for about 1.5 to 2 hours, or until the meat is tender.
Season with salt and white pepper to taste.
Garnish with chopped green onions and cilantro before serving.
Serve with steamed rice or youtiao (Chinese fried dough).

recipes.name: Popiah
ingredients: 100g tofu, sliced into strips and fried
steps: In a large wok or skillet, heat the vegetable oil over medium heat. Add the minced garlic and stir-fry until fragrant.
Add the jicama and stir-fry for a few minutes until slightly softened.
Add the cooked shrimp, tofu, bean sprouts, soy sauce, oyster sauce, hoisin sauce, sugar, and ground white pepper. Stir-fry until well combined and heated through.
Lay a popiah skin on a clean surface. Place a lettuce leaf on top.
Spoon the filling onto the lettuce leaf and add fresh mint leaves, cilantro leaves, and fried tofu slices.
Fold the sides of the popiah skin over the filling, then roll it up tightly.
Repeat with the remaining popiah skins and filling.
Slice each popiah roll in half, garnish with crushed peanuts, and drizzle with sweet sauce if desired.

recipes.name: Murtabak
steps: In a large skillet, heat the vegetable oil over medium heat. Add the chopped onions, minced garlic, and minced ginger. Sauté until fragrant and the onions are translucent.
Add the ground meat and cook until browned. Stir in the curry powder, chili powder, and salt. Cook for a few more minutes, then set aside to cool.
In a mixing bowl, combine the all-purpose flour with enough water to make a smooth, elastic dough. Divide the dough into balls.
Roll out each ball into a thin circle.
Spread a layer of the cooked meat mixture onto one half of the circle, leaving a border around the edges.
Fold the other half of the circle over the filling to create a half-moon shape. Press the edges to seal.
Heat a bit of vegetable oil in a skillet over medium heat. Dip the murtabak into the beaten eggs, then place it in the skillet.
Cook until golden brown on both sides.
Slice and garnish with chopped cilantro and green onions.

recipes.name: Rendang
steps: Blend all the spice paste ingredients in a food processor until smooth.
Heat the vegetable oil in a large pot over medium heat. Add the spice paste and sauté until fragrant.
Add the beef chunks and cook until browned on all sides.
Pour in the coconut milk and add the kaffir lime leaves, lemongrass, tamarind paste, coriander powder, cumin powder, chili powder, sugar, and salt.
Simmer on low heat for about 2-3 hours, or until the beef is tender and the sauce has thickened.
Serve with steamed rice.

recipes.name: Kueh Lapis
steps: Preheat the oven to 180°C (350°F). Grease an 8-inch square baking pan.
In a large mixing bowl, cream together the softened butter, sweetened condensed milk, and castor sugar until light and fluffy.
Gradually add in the tapioca flour and rice flour, mixing until well combined.
Divide the batter into two equal portions.
To one portion, add pandan extract and green food coloring (if using). Mix until the color is evenly distributed.
To the other portion, add cocoa powder and mix until well combined.
Spoon a thin layer of either the pandan or cocoa batter into the bottom of the greased pan and spread it out evenly.
Alternate between the pandan and cocoa batter, spreading each layer evenly, until all the batter is used up.
Bake in the preheated oven for about 30-40 minutes, or until the top is golden brown.
Allow the kueh lapis to cool before slicing into squares.

recipes.name: Chwee Kueh
ingredients: 200g preserved radish (chye poh), rinsed and finely chopped
steps: In a large bowl, whisk together the rice flour, wheat starch, water, and salt until smooth.
Pour the mixture into a greased steaming tray or individual cups.
Steam over high heat for about 15-20 minutes, or until the chwee kueh is set and firm.
While the chwee kueh is steaming, prepare the topping. Heat the vegetable oil in a pan over medium heat. Add the minced garlic and sauté until fragrant.
Add the preserved radish, sugar, soy sauce, and white pepper. Stir-fry for a few minutes until well combined and heated through.
Once the chwee kueh is cooked, allow it to cool slightly before removing it from the steaming tray or cups.
Top each chwee kueh with the radish mixture and garnish with chopped cilantro.

recipes.name: Tau Huay (Soy Pudding)
ingredients: 1 teaspoon gypsum powder (available at Asian grocery stores)
steps: In a bowl, whisk together the unsweetened soy milk powder and water until well combined.
In a saucepan, combine the sugar and gypsum powder. Gradually add the soy milk mixture, stirring continuously.
Heat the mixture over low heat, stirring constantly, until it thickens and begins to bubble.
Remove from heat and pour the mixture into molds or individual serving dishes.
Allow the tau huay to cool and set for about 2-3 hours.
Serve chilled, optionally with a drizzle of syrup or a sprinkle of crushed peanuts.

recipes.name: Ice Kachang
ingredients: 2 tablespoons colored syrup (rose, pandan, or other flavors)
steps: Place the shaved ice in a bowl or shallow dish.
Top the ice with red bean paste, grass jelly cubes, sweet corn kernels, attap chee, and nata de coco.
Drizzle colored syrup, condensed milk, and evaporated milk over the top.
Serve immediately and enjoy!

recipes.name: Teh Tarik
steps: Place the black tea leaves in a teapot.
Pour boiling water over the tea leaves and let steep for about 5 minutes.
Strain the tea into a separate pot, discarding the tea leaves.
Return the strained tea to the teapot and add the condensed milk.
Using a long ladle, 'pull' the tea from one pot to another several times to create a frothy top.
Serve hot in cups or glasses.

recipes.name: Bak Chor Mee
ingredients: Green onions and cilantro for garnish
steps: Cook the dried egg noodles according to package instructions. Drain and set aside.
In a large wok or skillet, heat the vegetable oil over medium heat. Add the minced garlic and stir-fry until fragrant.
Add the minced pork and cook until browned. Stir in the black vinegar, soy sauce, oyster sauce, and sugar. Add chili paste if desired.
Add the cooked noodles to the wok and toss until well combined and heated through.
Serve hot, garnished with green onions and cilantro.

recipes.name: Lor Mee
steps: Cook the flat yellow noodles according to package instructions. Drain and set aside.
In a large wok or skillet, heat the vegetable oil over medium heat. Add the minced garlic and stir-fry until fragrant.
Add the sliced braised pork belly and cook until heated through.
Pour in the broth and add the minced garlic, sliced ginger, star anise, and cinnamon stick. Bring to a simmer and let it cook for about 10 minutes.
Stir in the black vinegar, dark soy sauce, salt, and sugar. Thicken the broth with cornstarch mixture.
Serve the noodles in bowls, topped with the braised pork, hard-boiled eggs, and a ladle of the savory broth.

recipes.name: Mee Siam
ingredients: Bean sprouts, chives, and lime wedges for garnish
steps: Cook the rice vermicelli according to package instructions. Drain and set aside.
In a large wok or skillet, heat the vegetable oil over medium heat. Add the minced garlic and stir-fry until fragrant.
Push the ingredients to one side of the wok and pour the beaten eggs into the empty side. Scramble until just set, then mix with the other ingredients.
Add the cooked prawns and stir-fry for a few minutes.
Stir in the tamarind paste, sugar, soy sauce, and chili paste. Add the cooked rice vermicelli and toss until well combined and heated through.
Serve the Mee Siam with bean sprouts, chives, and lime wedges for garnish.

recipes.name: Bak Kwa
steps: In a bowl, combine all the ingredients except for the sesame seeds.
Mix well and marinate the minced pork for at least 4 hours or overnight in the refrigerator.
Preheat the oven to 180°C (350°F). Line a baking tray with parchment paper.
Spread the marinated minced pork onto the tray, forming a thin layer.
Bake for about 15-20 minutes, or until the pork is cooked and slightly caramelized.
Remove from the oven and let it cool before slicing into pieces.
Optional: Sprinkle sesame seeds on top before serving.

recipes.name: Mee Goreng Mamak
ingredients: Sliced cucumbers, tomatoes, and lime wedges for garnish
Fried shallots and chopped cilantro for garnish
steps: Soak the yellow noodles in hot water for about 15 minutes until softened. Drain and set aside.
Heat the vegetable oil in a large wok over high heat. Add the garlic and shallots, and stir-fry until fragrant.
Add the prawns and cook until they turn pink. Push the prawns to one side of the wok.
Pour the beaten eggs into the wok and scramble until just set. Mix with the prawns.
Add the shredded chicken, cooked noodles, kecap manis, soy sauce, and chili paste. Stir-fry until well combined and heated through.
Garnish with sliced cucumbers, tomatoes, and lime wedges. Top with fried shallots and chopped cilantro.

recipes.name: Hokkien Mee
ingredients: Bean sprouts and lime wedges for garnish
steps: Soak the yellow noodles in hot water for about 15 minutes until softened. Drain and set aside.
Heat the vegetable oil in a large wok over high heat. Add the minced garlic and shallots, and stir-fry until fragrant.
Add the prawns and squid, and cook until they turn pink and opaque.
Push the ingredients to one side of the wok and pour the beaten eggs into the empty side. Scramble until just set, then mix with the other ingredients.
Add the soaked noodles, soy sauce, oyster sauce, fish sauce, and chili paste. Stir-fry until well combined and heated through.
Serve the Hokkien Mee with bean sprouts and lime wedges for garnish.

recipes.name: Hae Mee Tng
ingredients: Salt and white pepper to taste
Bean sprouts, chopped cilantro, and lime wedges for garnish
steps: Peel and devein the prawns. Reserve the shells and heads.
In a large pot, heat the vegetable oil over medium heat. Add the minced garlic and sauté until fragrant.
Add the prawn shells and heads, along with the pork ribs. Cook until the prawn shells turn pink.
Pour in the chicken broth and water. Bring to a boil, then reduce heat and let it simmer for about 30-45 minutes.
Strain the broth, discarding the solids. Return the broth to the pot.
Add the fish sauce, salt, and white pepper to taste.
Cook the yellow noodles according to package instructions. Drain and set aside.
Blanch the prawns and cooked pork ribs in the broth until cooked through.
Divide the cooked noodles into bowls. Ladle the hot broth, prawns, and pork ribs over the noodles.
Serve with bean sprouts, chopped cilantro, and lime wedges.

recipes.name: Oyster Omelette (Orh Luak)
steps: In a small bowl, mix together the potato starch and water to make a slurry.
Heat a bit of vegetable oil in a non-stick skillet over medium heat. Add the shucked oysters and cook until they turn plump. Remove and set aside.
In the same skillet, add more oil if needed. Add the minced garlic and thinly sliced shallots. Sauté until fragrant.
Pour in the beaten eggs and let them cook for a minute.
Drizzle the potato starch slurry over the eggs and spread it out to create a thin layer.
Add the cooked oysters on top and cook for another minute, or until the bottom is golden brown.
Fold the omelette in half and cook for another minute, or until the omelette is cooked through.
In a small bowl, mix together the ingredients for the sauce.
Serve the oyster omelette hot, garnished with chopped cilantro and drizzled with the sauce.

recipes.name: Bak Chang
ingredients: 100g dried shiitake mushrooms, soaked and halved
steps: Soak the glutinous rice in water for at least 4 hours or overnight. Drain and set aside.
In a large wok or skillet, heat a bit of oil over medium heat. Add the minced garlic and sliced shallots, and stir-fry until fragrant.
Add the pork belly chunks and cook until browned on all sides.
Stir in the soaked shiitake mushrooms, chestnuts, and drained glutinous rice. Cook for a few minutes until well combined.
Divide the mixture into four portions.
To assemble each bak chang, lay out two soaked bamboo leaves, one on top of the other, to form a cross. Place a portion of the mixture in the center.
Add a salted duck egg yolk in the center of each portion.
Fold the bamboo leaves over the filling, creating a pyramid shape. Secure with kitchen twine.
Bring a large pot of water to a boil. Add the bak chang and boil for about 2-3 hours, or until the rice is cooked and the filling is tender.
Remove the bak chang from the water and allow them to cool before serving.

recipes.name: Nasi Lemak
steps: Rinse the rice until the water runs clear. Drain well.
In a large pot, combine the rice, coconut milk, and pandan leaves (if using). Cook the rice according to your preferred method (stovetop, rice cooker, or instant pot).
While the rice is cooking, prepare the sambal belacan and fry the anchovies and peanuts.
Once the rice is cooked, fluff it with a fork and season with salt to taste.
Serve the nasi lemak with hard-boiled eggs, fried anchovies, fried peanuts, cucumber slices, and a dollop of sambal belacan.

recipes.name: Mee Rebus
ingredients: 2 tablespoons sweet potato flour (or cornstarch), mixed with water
Bean sprouts and lime wedges for garnish
steps: Soak the yellow noodles in hot water for about 15 minutes until softened. Drain and set aside.
In a large wok or skillet, heat the vegetable oil over medium heat. Add the minced garlic and stir-fry until fragrant.
Add the prawns and cook until they turn pink. Push the prawns to one side of the wok.
Pour the beaten eggs into the empty side of the wok and scramble until just set. Mix with the prawns.
Stir in the tamarind paste, sweet potato flour mixture, sugar, soy sauce, and chili paste. Add the soaked noodles and toss until well combined and heated through.
Serve the Mee Rebus with bean sprouts and lime wedges for garnish.

recipes.name: Kueh Dadar
steps: In a mixing bowl, combine the glutinous rice flour, pandan juice, and coconut milk. Mix until a smooth batter forms.
In a saucepan, melt the grated gula melaka with a bit of water over low heat, stirring until it forms a syrup. Set aside.
Heat a non-stick skillet over low heat. Pour a ladle of the batter onto the skillet, spreading it out thinly.
Cook until the edges start to lift, then flip and cook for a few more seconds. Remove from the skillet and set aside.
Repeat with the remaining batter.
Place a spoonful of the gula melaka syrup onto each pancake and roll it up.
Roll the kueh dadar in desiccated coconut to coat the outside.
Slice and serve.

recipes.name: Kway Chap
ingredients: Chopped cilantro and green onions for garnish
steps: In a large pot, blanch the rice noodles in boiling water until just tender. Drain and set aside.
In a separate pot of boiling water, blanch the pig offal until cooked. Drain and set aside.
In a large wok or skillet, heat the vegetable oil over medium heat. Add the minced garlic and stir-fry until fragrant.
Add the sliced tofu and cook until golden brown. Remove and set aside.
In the same wok, add a bit more oil if needed. Stir in the blanched rice noodles.
Add the dark soy sauce, light soy sauce, oyster sauce, five-spice powder, white pepper, and black vinegar. Toss until well combined and heated through.
Serve the kway chap with the pig offal, tofu, hard-boiled eggs, and garnish with chopped cilantro and green onions.

recipes.name: Chilli Crab
ingredients: 2 mud crabs, cleaned and cut into pieces
Steamed buns or rice for serving
steps: In a large wok or skillet, heat the vegetable oil over medium heat. Add the minced garlic and ginger and stir-fry until fragrant.
Add the crab pieces and cook until they turn red.
Stir in the tomato ketchup, sweet chili sauce, soy sauce, oyster sauce, and sugar. Toss until well combined.
Dissolve the cornstarch in water and pour it into the wok. Stir until the sauce thickens.
Garnish with chopped cilantro and serve with steamed buns or rice.

recipes.name: Kaya Toast
steps: Toast the slices of white bread until golden brown and crisp.
Spread a generous layer of kaya on two of the toasted slices.
In a small bowl, mix together the soy sauce and white pepper. Dip the soft-boiled eggs in the mixture.
Place an egg on top of each slice of kaya-covered bread.
Top with the remaining slices of toasted bread.
Cut each sandwich into halves or quarters and serve with black coffee with condensed milk.
